title: Embattled Mulvaney draws a sudden wave of support from key conservatives
text:
It’s part of an effort by conservatives to shore up support for Mulvaney, a former South Carolina congressman and founding member of the House Freedom Caucus, as the approval of his West Wing leadership ebbs and flows among top White House officials and even the president. Some Trump allies have been circulating names in recent days of possible replacements for Mulvaney as chief of staff. A group of conservatives decided to write the letter during a meeting in Washington last week, according to a second source familiar with the process.

The conservatives’ letter to the White House chalks the criticism of Mulvaney to the “D.C. Swamp” attacking him.

Mulvaney faced strong criticism over the last week for two televised appearances — first during a White House briefing and then a Fox News Sunday interview in which he tried to clarify details of the Ukraine scandal only to raise more questions about his and the president’s involvement in holding up aid to Ukraine. Democrats seized on his comments as evidence that the White House engaged in a quid pro quo, threatening to withhold funding to Ukraine until its leaders agreed to investigate former vice president Joe Biden and his son.

Inside the White House, Mulvaney and his aides have also been at odds with other White House staffers and attorneys over control and the best course of action on the administration’s impeachment strategy.

An administration official said Mulvaney did not know about the letter until he saw news reports about it on Thursday.

To key parts of the conservative movement, Mulvaney remains a strong leader.

“As director of the Office of Management and Budget and as acting White House chief of staff, Mulvaney has overseen the office most responsible for implementing the Trump agenda throughout the government. His attention, vision, and commitment to the president’s policies have been evident from the beginning of the administration to today. We believe the president should make him permanent in the chief of staff role,” the letter says.
